text: Malignant transformation usually inhibits terminal cell differentiation but the precise mechanisms involved are not understood .
<extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a hematopoietic - specific Ets family transcription factor that is required for development of some lymphoid and myeloid lineages .

<extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can also act as an oncoprotein as activation of its expression in erythroid precursors by proviral insertion or transgenesis causes erythroleukemias in mice .

text: Restoration of terminal differentiation in the mouse erythroleukemia ( MEL ) cells requires a decline in the level of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , indicating that <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can block erythroid differentiation .

text: Here we investigate the mechanism by which <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interferes with erythroid differentiation .

We find that <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interacts directly with <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a zinc finger transcription factor required for erythroid differentiation .

text: <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> represses <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated transcriptional activation .

Both the DNA binding and transactivation domains of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are required for repression and both domains are also needed to block terminal differentiation in MEL cells .
We also show that ectopic expression of <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Xenopus embryos is sufficient to block erythropoiesis during normal development .

Furthermore , introduction of exogenous <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in both MEL cells and Xenopus embryos and explants relieves the block to erythroid differentiation imposed by <extra_id_0> PU.1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Our results indicate that the stoichiometry of directly interacting but opposing transcription factors may be a crucial determinant governing processes of normal differentiation and malignant transformation .
